Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Awards: Impact of wave on the dynamics of a coastal plume

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Research Initiation Award project entitled - Impact of Wave on the Dynamics of a Coastal Plume - has the goal to use observational data and numerical modeling experiments to answer three questions about coastal plume dynamics: do wave fields modify coastal plume dynamics; do the river plumes impact on the surface gravity wave field; and is the interaction between the wave field and bathymetry a key factor for the formation of coastal plume dynamics? The research seeks to obtain an understanding of plume dynamics, estuary-ocean water exchange and estuary/coastal wave-current interaction, including the estuarine dynamics of Maryland Coastal Bays and Chesapeake Bay. The educational goal of the project is to increase the engagement of African American undergraduate students in ocean and coastal science research.

Many previous plume studies have been focused on correlations between external forcing such as wind or river runoff and plume dynamics. The novelty of this project is its approach to consider the effects of a wave field on plume dynamics and circulation processes. The observational data will provide the historic analysis between plume dynamics for different wave types under other similar external forcing. High resolution numerical models will analyze the effects of waves, such as wave height, period, direction and the plume formation to complement the observational data to enhance an understanding of the effect of waves on plume formation. An understanding of plume dynamics is critical to the understanding of such issues as nutrient loading and eutrophication, bacterial contamination of beaches, carbon exchange and juvenile fish, crab and oyster recruitment. The nearshore circulation induced estuarine plume dynamics could be potentially linked to the life histories of estuarine dependent fish migrations. Given the important relationship of river plumes with the larval transport and fish migration, this work has implications for the shelf-to-estuary transport of pollutants and/or the larval transport and survival of important marine species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our specific objectives are: (1) Configuring the unstructured-grid-based wave-circulation-trajectory modeling system to Grand Haven and Lake Michigan; (2) Improving the modeling of surface waves, coastal hydrodynamics and particle trajectory/plume dynamics. (3) Investigating and revealing complex interactions among bathymetry, surface waves, nearshore currents, and coastal plume/temperature.

 

The unstructured-grid based wave model SWAN has been configured to Grand Haven and Lake Michigan, and then it was incorporated for Wave-Current Interaction (WCI) coupled FVCOM/SWAVE. After modeling calibration and validation, it was used to further investigate of the effects of surface waves on coastal plume dynamics. In order to examine the effects of surface waves on coastal circulation and plume dynamics, the wave-circulation-trajectory coupled modeling system was configured to Grand Haven and Lake Michigan.

 

The modeling of wind waves indicates that the bathymetry influences the wavefield through depth-induced breaking in the shallow waters (Mao, van der Westhuysen and Xia et al. (2016a). The ability in resolving coastal bathymetry is significant to improve the simulation of the wavefield, and the breaking of shallow-water waves will further result in wave-induced setup and setdown, and corresponding alongshore and offshore/onshore currents. Through the modification to the water circulation, the formation of coastal plume could then be impacted. So the predicting accuracy of coastal currents is crucial to the basin-scale and coastal circulation simulation and the formulation of coastal plume.

 

The effects of temperature on modifying the nearshore current are also discussed in Mao and Xia (2016d), which reported that the nearshore current in the middle and bottom layers along the southern coast of Lake Michigan is determined by the titling of isotherms. The wave-circulation-trajectory modeling system was further validated using the observations from lake bottom temperature near the southeastern coast and the vertical currents profile near the mid-western coast. In addition, eleven surface drifters were deployed in summer 2014, 2015 and their movements were tracked along the Grand Haven and its adjacent eastern coasts. The simulations indicate that the inclusion of surface waves could impact the current velocity field, and it particularly can influence the particle trajectories/plume through wave–current interactions (WCI), especially in the shallow waters near the coast. Overall, the intensity of nearshore current from surface to middle layer is reduced to some extent, and even becomes vanished in the bottom layer.

 

At the same time, the modifications of plume/temperature on the nearshore current, especially near Grand Haven Inlet, are discussed in Xia and Mao (2016c) and Mao and Xia (2016d). It was noticed that the density-driven (i.e., temperature or thermal gradients) currents are significant in the formation of strong coastal currents (e.g., diameter between 50–500 km) in the coasts. Even though the variation of particle trajectories simulated by the particle tracking model with and without surface heat flux or river inflow are not as significant as that of the wind, it is still necessary to include the baroclinic process and river input in the particle tracking modeling to yield an accurate simulation of particle trajectories/plume dynamics (Mao and Xia, 2016c).

 

Overall, the significant results are: (1) The ability of resolving the complex nearshore bathymetry and the inclusion of surface waves are key factors responsible for the coastal plume dynamics and the alongshore particle trajectories near the Grand Haven area and the eastern coast; (2) Even though the wave effects have little effect monthly averaged nearshore circulation, it plays an important role in the particle trajectories/plume dynamics at Grand Haven along the eastern coast; (3) The temperature could modify the nearshore circulation through the density-driven currents, especially during the thermally stratified summer season.

 

Numerous undergraduate and graduate students (particularly minority and women students) gained training from this project, and one master thesis was supported. In additional, one paper focusing on the wave dynamics was published in the Journal of Geophysical Research: Oceans (Mao and Xia et al., 2016a, first paper published supported by this project). One manuscript regarding the wave–current–surge interactions in Lake Michigan is under revision by Ocean Modelling. Two manuscripts investigating the effects of waves, currents, and bathymetry on coastal plume and temperature field will be be submitted to the Journal of Physical Oceanography and Ocean Dynamics:

 

  • Mao, M., A.J. van der Westhuysen, M. Xia, D.J. Schwab, and A. Chawla (2016a), Modeling wind waves from deep to shallow waters in Lake Michigan using unstructured SWAN, J. Geophys. Res., 121, 3836–3865.

 

  • Mao, M., and M. Xia, (2016b), Investigation of storm surge and wave–current interactions in Lake Michigan by model comparisons. Under revision by Ocean Modell.

 

  • M. Xia and Mao, M. (2016c), Investigation of summer circulation dynamics in Lake Michigan using wave–circulation-trajectory modeling system. To be submitted to J. Phys. Oceanogr.

 

  • Mao, M., and M. Xia, (2016d), Numerical simulation of three-dimensional summer circulation in southern Lake Michigan. To be submitted to Ocean Dynam.
